comments.commentBody:
I completely agree that we should solicit the best and the brightest to immigrate to the US. They have been key drivers for innovation and economic growth. It should be the goal of a selective, pragmatic immigration program.

However, the majority of those effected by proposed amnesty are largely illiterate, and have limited skills.

Many strongly resist absorption into our culture and cannot speak our native language. The result has been Balkanized ghettos. Reform will not change this behavior.

If reform is enacted, many immigrants will become wards of the state, as they will be competing for an ever shrinking pools of low skill, low wage jobs. They are destined to further bankrupt our social safety net. We do not need 11 million people to pick fruit. This is not bigotry, it is painful fact.

What about near-constant tracking and verification of B1, L1 and H1b visas?  Remember the $34 Million paid by Infosys when their B1 visas were checked? Somehow I think $34 million is not nearly equal the profit these companies are getting for blatant violations. And that $34 million  will not compensate the American STEM workers who lost their jobs during the period of visa abuse and AFTER when Infosys had to cut on-site "senior" staff (code for American workers) in order to keep their profits up. Just who is the electorate nowadays?
What open borders outfit do you work for???
There will be pickets and as much media as we can muster to make sure anyone who votes for  this is outed at the next election. After all, what else will we have to do with our time?

Mark -

You really need to look at trends when you judge other countries. Look at the health of these countries BEFORE they were inundated with multinational corporate fast food restaurants and GMO.

What is one of our biggest exports? McDonald's.
Some of these countries were far better off before.

Actually PGD mostly eliminates embryos that would never implant or would miscarry if they did. By doing PGD, a couple avoids the pain of miscarriage and increases the chances of IVF success. Also in Amy's case, if there are no "normal" embryos, its a sign that IVF wont work for her.

The person who claimed that only in the inner cities do the elderly congregate at McDonald's (etc.) is clearly wrong. I have seen the same thing going on for years in small towns and suburbs in Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, and New Jersey. These places become significant anchors of social life, as Anderson, Duneier, and Oldenburg demonstrate.

I am sympathetic to the desire of elderly people for an interesting, intergenerational place to socialize. It's understandable that many seniors prefer gathering in restaurants to gathering in what they perceive to be dull or stigmatized senior centers.

This is a challenge for urban planners: to require that such public gathering places be designed into urban commercial zones and, ideally, financed with dedications from developers. The spaces should be usable year round, and offer retail access.

As to whether the local McDonald's should be required to offer such access: seniors should make purchases to secure access, just like younger patrons, during peak hours. Accommodations, such as the 'bottomless cup of coffee' cited by Stacy Torres, can be made off-peak at the discretion of management.

This made me so sad. I know that part of the country, have some family there. This young woman seems like a kind and loving person, with little chance at climbing out of poverty.  TV shows, so-called reality shows have given her the idea that she can have a big house in her future. Someone forgot to spread the word that an education is important, and so is birth control. That goes for pets, too. Just sad all around, and sad for all her little sisters who will doubtless follow in her footsteps.

She does have an idea of what's coming, a repeat of her mother's life, and she's right, and that's why, for all she lacks, she's so disturbingly comfortable in her skin. What she has no idea of is how to create other better possibilities.

Having a baby, when your are broke, is an anchoring maneuver; the state steps in to assure your survival. Staying single, hitting the books, moving to a place with work, finding a way to college, that's all rough sailing in uncharted seas. She's choosing to deal with the devil she knows. At age 15 what can be expected, she has no better guidance, apparently.

Mr. Friedman's piece, which some may criticize as too Arab population growth-focused or otherwise simplistic, is nonetheless quite valuable.  It points to evidence that Maltusian factors (i.e., human numbers outstripping productive capacity of the land) have contributed the tragedy in Syria.  No thoughtful commentator (including Mr. Friedman) would suggest this was inevitable (as would a so-called Neo-Maltusian).  To reinforce his point, governments' (which some may argue includes the US) functionally unable support their peoples' capacity to adapt socially and technologically are at risk of collapse from internal and external environmental forces.  These include climate variability, whether on not human caused.  Suggesting the proxy warring countries should be investing in Syria's "resiliency" (or "resilience" as it is called in ecology and reference climate change adaptation) is appropriate, even if beyond wishful thinking.

Bob -- World population today is three times what it was sixty years ago.  It is just over 8 billion today, and was 2 point something billion 60 years ago (exact number debated).  Quadrupling is not so much more as to account for the extreme events there and no elsewhere that it went up as much or more.

Correction:

World population Jan 2014 - 7.14 billion

World population 1954 - 2.6 billion

The world population has increased by a factor of 2.7 in the last 60 years.

Friedman quotes an Israeli about the expansion of Arab populations, without noting that in the past 60 years, the Jewish population of Israel has expanded a lot more. He does not note the political pressure around the "population bomb" concerns. He does not note that since WW2 even the US population has doubled. The whole world has more than doubled in that period. His lack of balance in the comment reflects the Israeli fixation with Arab population size. It is not an Arab problem, it is a world problem.

The Syrian farms failed before the present war. Their failure was a contributing factor to the start of the war. They fell far below past performance, so it wasn't just a failure to keep up. The farming failure in Syria needs fair explanation, far beyond just that there are too many Syrians.

Why did world population explode after WW2? Vaccination and medical care kept children alive, and the Green Revolution ended mass starvation. Syria is far from the most explosive population growth, all from these same factors.

Starvation and population crash is not a feature of anyplace in our modern world. Population stress is not unique in Syria, not even in the top. It cannot explain this war. That fixation reflects the fixations of those to whom Friedman listens, and their demographic concern to enable their own even greater expansion.

Friedman repeats these mantras without apparent recognition of context.
If the monster listens in? My instinct would be, everybody pick a random color.

Woe is you.

You truly are bearing the burden of Job.

The preparation for the snowfall and the lack of response in terms of salting and plowing once the blizzard began were miserable. I'm truly disappointed. It was several hours before Broadway saw its first plows. What were these guys thinking?

Woe is you.

You truly are bearing the burden of Job.

"Several hours" before you saw plows on Broadway?  The horror!  That's the *norm* in *most* of the city, a.k.a. "the outer boroughs".  Snow removal equipment and manpower needs to be shared equitably - and there's usually more snow outside Manhattan.

The preparation for the snowfall and the lack of response in terms of salting and plowing once the blizzard began were miserable. I'm truly disappointed. It was several hours before Broadway saw its first plows. What were these guys thinking?

Is this another Chris Christie act of retribution?

If so, what ticked him off this time?

(Just a non-Republican taking a page from the GOP "Obama is to blame for everything" Playbook.)

Is this another Chris Christie act of retribution?

If so, what ticked him off this time?

(Just a non-Republican taking a page from the GOP "Obama is to blame for everything" Playbook.)

Should be obvious by now that deBlasio is more interested in raising taxes on the rich as some kind of ideological victory. Cuomo is the more sensible person because he the broader view of a governor who sees his state losing population and employers every year.

As a de Blasio supporter, I think his response to Cuomo's offer is hasty and goofy.  If de Blasio can institutionalize universal pre-K in NYC in the next four years and move closer to the governor, he has a powerful opportunity to consolidate power.  It seems stupid and naive of him to turn down Cuomo's offer, as long as NYC gets the same amount of money de Blasio proposed for the program.  It's a rookie move to let the press goad you into a conflict when the governor of your party basically flattered you by taking universal pre-K state-wide.  I hope de Blasio understands how to play politics in NY.

All or nothing and you're going to get nothing.  The future of America will boil down to which group of extremists the great big group of us in the middle are most fed up with.  When the DeBlasio left wants to turn America into Venezuela,  Rand Paul starts sounding like the voice of reason.  Heaven help us.

But the plan has been on the books in NY state for years and nothing was ever funded, and it never came to fruition. Cuomo never did anything about it, but now that he sees how popular the idea is in the city, he wants to trumpet his idea.
"New York has had universal prekindergarten on the books since 1997, but it has never been close to fully funded; recessions curtailed the program’s growth, and many local districts, which are required to pay for part of it themselves, never bothered."
Seems to me, I wouldn't wait around for the state any more either if I were DeBlasio.

If the city government that we elected in the city wants to raise CITY taxes why does the State have any say in it?  It's insane.  There's no reason legislators from Buffalo or Plattsburgh should be voting on whether NYC gets to raise or lower it's own income tax.   And for that matter I don't think it's right for my legislators that I elect from NYC to be telling the people of Plattsburgh if they can change their taxes.

Suppose m is a multiple of n, that is, m = kn. We might assign all the numbers from 1 to m to the people so that each person gets k different numbers. Each player randomly and secretly chooses one of his numbers to use for the (mod m) subtraction. Even if the monster knows the overall strategy, the people have 1/k chance of winning.

This strategy can be slightly modified for the situation where m is not an exact multiple of n, and the chance of winning is still greater than 1/(k+1).
So I guess it's OK to have your staff stop traffic on the nation's busiest bridge and paralyze an entire town with gridlock for four days out of pure spite as long you apologize for them afterward?
Who wrote that lengthy, repetitive oath?
Thank you - now, call your congessman and senator.
STEM qualifications are Not verified now, to our detriment; the average H1b is not especially competent and, in my experience, very few of them are.  Existing laws must be enforced.

Idiotic drivel.  Most all the employers I have worked with will not hire natives on the ground that they are not pliable enough.  If we want to integrate foreign countries then we should make Haiti, Mexico and Guatemala states in the US with US laws and work rules.  The way we are doing it leads to us getting the financial responsibility without the land and resources to build prosperity.  We could make Haiti a great resort area.  We could extend California southward.
